content.user_title: Develop FigJam plugins with two-thread architecture
content.value_statement: FigJam plugin development requires understanding Figma API constraints and WebSocket communication patterns. This skill provides guidance on building, debugging, and deploying plugins that render AWS architecture diagrams in FigJam canvases.
actual_capabilities: Guide two-thread plugin development (main thread and UI thread)
Explain Figma API constraints for main thread code
Debug WebSocket communication between CLI and plugin
Build plugin with bun and import to Figma Desktop
Handle JSON import validation and normalization
Debug plugin using browser DevTools and Figma console
limitations: Requires Figma Desktop app, not available in browser
Main thread cannot use browser APIs (window, document, fetch)
WebSocket server must be running separately via CLI
Limited to Figma plugin API capabilities

faq.question: What is the difference between code.ts and ui.ts in FigJam plugins?
faq.answer: code.ts runs on main thread with Figma API access only. ui.ts runs in iframe with browser APIs and WebSocket support.

faq.question: Can I use this plugin in Figma browser editor?
faq.answer: No. FigJam plugins require Figma Desktop app. Browser editor does not support custom plugin development.

faq.question: How do I debug WebSocket connection issues?
faq.answer: Open browser DevTools on plugin UI (right-click â†’ Inspect) to see connection status and error messages in console.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this plugin?
faq.answer: Yes. Plugin runs locally with WebSocket server on localhost. No data is sent to external servers.

faq.question: Why is my code.ts failing with undefined errors?
faq.answer: Main thread cannot use browser APIs. Ensure no window, document, or fetch calls in code.ts. Use figma.* API only.

faq.question: How does this compare to other diagram tools?
faq.answer: This tool uses YAML for architecture definitions and syncs live to FigJam. Unlike draw.io, it offers version-controlled diagrams.
